column5: These arrows represent country-to-country aid donations between 1973 and 2013
Each arrow represents the sum of donations from one country to another
column6: Darker, larger arrows indicate larger donation sums between countries
Major donor countries should have a lot of arrows leaving their shores, but few coming back.  Can you pick out the major donors?

column5: Net donors vs net receivers of aid
column6: Countries that donated more than they received are reds/oranges, whereas countries that received more than they donated are blues

column5: Countries in the middle of the color scale have smaller or near zero net flow of aid
column6: Smaller donations may be a result of the size of their country GDP or a result of roughly equal donation / receipt of aid over time.
Let's drill down into some of the patterns we mentioned earlier by focusing on the countries instead of the actual flows.

Shaping the countries as circles highlights the donor/recipient trends nicely: here we're scaling by magnitude of donations.

Notice that the US, Japan, Germany (DEU), and France are the largest donors.

Larger donors in the Middle East include Kuwait (KWT) Saudi Arabia (SAU), and the United Arab Emirates (ARE).

column5: Who donates to whom? United States
column6:
The US is one of the two largest donors and donated to nearly every country in the world. However, there are still clear trends in US Aid, with the largest donations go to Egypt, Iraq, Israel, Afghanistan, and Pakistan.

In this view, arrows are sized relative to all net donations,
and shaded by net donation within the focus country, so darker arrows indicate the largest donations for a given country.

Japan also has a wide ranging donation profile, but donates significant amounts to a few nearby countries. Japan has the largest single donation sum of any country, with $59 Billion going to Indonesia, and smaller (but still very large) donations going to China and India.

column5: Who donates to whom? Explore for yourself!
column6: Hover over any donor country to see their donation "portfolio".

We can also scale by magnitude of aid received.

Indonesia (IDN), India (IND), China (CHN), and Brazil (BRA) have received the most aid: not surprising given their relatively large geographic sizes and populations.
